text: Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: You know smaller volume, here, three to six ounces rather than eight/ten. Family Member: Okay, okay. Is it, did it matter if he’s gluten free not? Doctor: Yeah, there isn’t anything about gluten-free diets and prostate cancer. You know how he feels on having the gluten uh. It’s not an association with prostate cancer. Family Member: And cancer in general? Doctor: You can that way. Family Member: How about rice—brown rice, white rice? Doctor: Yeah, if he’s going to have rice we prefer the brown rice Family Member: Yeah, that’s what she thought. She was asking about beans. Doctor: Well. Family Member: Like navy beans. Doctor: All beans are good.

text: Patient: Oh, I hope my teeth can stand it. (sighs) Doctor: Okay. So we saw you the beginning of April. How you feeling? Patient: Okay. Patient: I have to, I have to sit. I did mow the grass, but, um, it gets. Patient: Nope. I don’t do much at all. Doctor: And what are you missin’ out on? Doctor: So you’re not – (housework) Patient: Yeah. Chores. (Pause) Doctor: But it gets done the next day or next – or you get it done eventually – or? Patient: Eventually. text: Patient: Okay. Okay. That works. Doctor: Questions? Family Member: I do, I think that, uh, one of the, I guess, questions that came up in my mind was the signs of the cancer development in the adrenal is it consistent that it would be prostate cancer or we just don’t even know Doctor: Yeah. I mean, the assumption is that it is prostate cancer. Why give him a second cancer? Uh. So, that’s the assumption. You know, the adrenal gland can have benign tumors in it. Okay? Um. You know, if prostate cancer went in there, that would be a possible reason why it would bleed. Um. Sometimes the adrenal gland just doesn’t get a good blood supply, and it does bleed. Or, if you’re under stress, or like today with your blood pressure shooting through the roof, but your scans were yesterday. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh. It’s pretty nonspecific. Your aspirin puts you at a higher risk for like various Doctor: -things, such as bleeding. Patient: Okay. Should I stop that? Doctor: No. I mean, my sense is you’ve been on it for some reason. I, but, we didn’t start it, right? Patient: Yeah, yeah. My, um, primary doctor did. Doctor: So, you know, that would be the person to check. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Uh those pills they didn’t do anything. Doctor: Okay well don’t stop taking ‘em because… Patient: Well I took ‘em. Patient: Well you know I ordered some more yeah. Doctor: Oh you got a refill. Patient: I haven’t been doing better. text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So my hope is that with time the fatigue will get better. Patient: Is that a good thing because the testosterone feeds cancer, right? Doctor: Well, it’s a good thing and a bad thing. It’s a double-edged sword. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But you and I made the decision when we first met after a discussion with Dr.__ as well – Dr. – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - um that the side effects from the hormone therapies were getting a little bit too much for you. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your preference, which I agreed with at the time, was to stop the Lupron you get. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And given that your PSA level is very low, it was an investment point level, that you basically stop that, allow the testosterone to recover if you did good by itself, and then to monitor the PSA to see where that was at. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: From when I talk to people, first dose of chemo, most of the guys that I talk to, not a huge impact effect with nausea or, or anything. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um - Doctor: In my experience, the first cycle is the hardest in some ways, ‘cuz you just don’t know what to expect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, when am I gonna feel tired? They told me I’m going to have aches. They told me this, and then if it happens or some of it happens. Uh, so we’re trying to give you. But usually, that first cycle sorta gives you your pattern. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I felt good, and then I felt tired, and then I was really wiped out, I had to sleep a lot that week and then I felt really good and they had to do it again. (laughter) Patient: Where would I find that information? Healthcare Professional: Like the timing? Of the course -- Patient: No, the, eh, um. The aches and pains, I got a bunch of them. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Patient: Just, more -- But like the ridges on the nailbeds. ‘Cuz if I, if I notice something that is abnormal and say, “MMmmm.” I’m gonna make a phone call. But that’s gonna just doesn’t make sense. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. In your consent, it has adverse things to expect, what are more common, what are less common. It’s in your consent. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ve got to find out about that. Those are the two I’m going to look at. Okay? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then I’m going to look at what is the Xtandi going to cost us, and, you know, hopefully within the next two days, I’ll have the answer to all that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
